bioghist.p: George Miksch Sutton (1898 - 1982) was an American ornithologist and bird artist. He published numerous technical papers in ornithology as well as more popular works illustrated with his own art. His early artistic work was inspired and tutored by Louis Agassiz Fuertes. In 1931, he was the first ornithologist to find the eggs of the Harris's Sparrow, one of the last North American birds to have its nest and eggs described. He did extensive field work in the Arctic (including Iceland), Oklahoma, Labrador, and Mexico. He received his doctorate from Cornell University and held academic posts at the University of Michigan and the University of Oklahoma, Norman.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of 17 drawings of birds by George Miksch Sutton used in The Birds of Columbia by Rodolphe Meyer de Schauensee (1964) (originally used to illustrated J. Van Tyne's Fundamentals of Ornithology, 1959). The collection also includes a "Chart of a Bird" by Maude Meyer de Schauensee, which was also used in Birds of Columbia.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
